{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=August 2014}} {{original research|date=May 2008}} }}
{{Politics of the African Union mini|institutions|width=5em}}
The '''African Unification Front''' ('''AUF''') is an organisation aiming to promote the [[political]], [[social]] and [[economic]] union of [[Africa]].
==History== AUF was formed in August 1996. The AUF advocates for transformation of Africa into a federation, with the [[Pan African Parliament]] as the highest government, overseeing key institutions including a single currency, and one all-African army. The AUF promoted the creation of the [[African Union]] in the mid-1990s<ref>{{cite book|last1=Telò (ed.)|first1=Professor Mario|title=Globalisation, Multilateralism, Europe: Towards a Better Global Governance?, Section 2.1|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ntn6AgAAQBAJ&pg=PT452&dq=African+Unification+Front&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=African%20Unification%20Front&f=false|date=2014|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd|isbn=9781472405388}}</ref> and continues to advocate for an end to neocolonialism. It has also been active in campaigns against abuses by the diamond industry, weapons traders, and unfair [[terms of trade]] in the [[coffee]] industry.
==Organization== The AUF National Committee is the body that elects the AUF president. The AUF Executive Committee is the body that implements policies and oversees the day-to-day administration of the AUF. AUF has been responsible for initiating and organizing several strategies, including the AUF's Fairtrade Coffee Campaign that pushed for reforms in the coffee industry.
The AUF, also known as the [[African Front]], consists of a worldwide network of supporters, who believe that Africa must be unified into a [[federation]] as a means of securing peace and an end to [[war]]s and [[poverty]]. Although most members of the AUF are Africans, membership is open to non-Africans.
===Past leaders=== Other past AUF leaders have been Fesseha Demessae who served as Deputy Secretary General and Director of Cultural Affairs, and former vice-president [[Mongezi Sefika wa Nkomo]].
[[Kirimi Kaberia]] was the first president of the AUF. [[Mouhamed Taofic Youssouf]] served briefly as AUF president, after Kirimi Kaberia accepted a posting as deputy ambassador for Kenya in Washington DC, USA.
==In the PAP== Following the creation of the [[Pan African Parliament]], the AUF became the first All-African (continental) political party. Several PAP members are also members and supporters of the AUF.
AUF members who have served in the Pan African Parliament include Dr. [[Amani Walid Kabourou]] from Tanzania, [[Chrispin Mwitila Shumina]] from Zambia, and [[Loyce Bwambale]] from Uganda. Other influential supporters of the AUF include [[John Atta-Mills]] the president of Ghana, [[Alhaji Yahaya Ndu]] who is also a member of the AUF National Committee and the president of the [[African Renaissance Party]] in Nigeria, [[Alimamy Bakarr Sankoh]], head of the [[Sierra Leone People's Democratic League]] (PDL), and Dr. [[Miria Matembe]],<ref>[http://www.africanfront.com/AF042.php africanfront.com (AUF)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> formerly chair of the Pan African Parliament's Rules Committee and a close ally of AU President [[Gertrude Mongella]].
==Symbols== The [[Maure]] is used as the AUF's [[flag]] and [[emblem]].
==See also== * [[Maure]] * [[African Union]]
==References== {{Reflist}}<!--added above External links/Sources by script-assisted edit-->
==External links== [http://www.africanfront.org/index.php Organisation's website]
{{Pan-Africanism}}

{{onesource|date=May 2017}} {{infobox military conflict |conflict =Battle of Mbandi Kasi |partof =the [[First Kongo-Portuguese War]] |image = |caption = |date =January 1623{{citation | last=Thornton | first=John | year=2010 | title=A RE-INTERPRETATION OF THE KONGO-PORTUGUESE WAR OF 1622 ACCORDING TO NEW DOCUMENTARY EVIDENCE | journal=The Journal of African History| volume=51, no. 2| pages=235-248| jstor=40985072}} |place =Mbandi Kasi, [[Angola]] |coordinates = |map_type = |map_relief = |latitude = |longitude = |map_size = |map_marksize = |map_caption = |map_label = |territory = |result =Decisive Kongolose victory |status = |combatants_header = |combatant1 =[[Image:Flag Portugal (1578).svg|23px|border]] [[Portuguese Angola]] |combatant2 =[[File:Flag of the Kingdom of Kongo.svg|23px|border]] [[Kingdom of Kongo]] |commander1 =Captain Major [[Pedro de Sousa Coelho]] |commander2 =King of Kongo [[Pedro II of Kongo|Pedro II]]
Count of Soyo [[Dom Antonio Manuel]] |strength1 =Several thousand Mbundu archers
Several thousand Portuguese infantry and Imbangla mercenaries |strength2 =Unknown |casualties1 =Heavy losses |casualties2 =Unknown |notes = |campaignbox ={{Portuguese colonial campaigns}} }} The '''Battle of Mbandi Kasi''' was a military engagement between forces of [[Portuguese Angola]] and the [[Kingdom of Kongo]] during their first armed conflict which spanned from 1622 to 1623. The battle, while not widely reported by the Portuguese, was recorded in correspondence between the Kongolese and their Dutch allies. The battle marked the turn of the short war in the favor of Kongo and led to the ouster of the Portuguese governor of Luanda and the return of Kongolese subjects taken as slaves in earlier campaigns. ==Footnotes== {{reflist|1}} ==See also== *[[First Kongo-Portuguese War]] *[[Portuguese Angola]] *[[Kingdom of Kongo]] *[[History of Angola]] {{coord missing|Angola}} [[Category:Battles involving Portugal|Mbandi Kasi]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1623|Mbandi Kasi]] [[Category:1623 in Africa]] [[Category:Battles in Angola|Mbandi Kasi]] [[Category:Portuguese Angola]] {{battle-stub}} {{Africa-hist-stub}}

{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=February 2012}} {{advert|date=February 2012}} }} {{Infobox TV channel | name = Body in Balance | logofile =Blue_hustler.png | logoalt = | launch = 2 June 2008 ([[UK]]) | share = 5.0% | share as of = March 2009 | share source = [http://www.barb.co.uk/viewingsummary/monthreports.cfm?report=monthgmulti BARB] | owner = Body In Balance Limited | timeshift names =Body in Balance +1 | web = [http://www.bodyinbalance.tv/ bodyinbalance.tv] | sat serv 1 = [[Astra 1L]] | sat chan 1 = 12574.25 H 22000 5/6 | sat serv 2 = Atlantic Bird 2 | sat chan 2 = 10972.00 V 27500 3/4 | sat serv 3 = [[CanalDigitaal]] ([[Netherlands]]) | sat chan 3 = Channel 68 (Germany only )
Channel 61 (Netherlands only) | cable serv 1 = Kabel BW ([[Germany]]) | cable chan 1 = Channel 617 | cable serv 2 = [[Kabel Deutschland]] ([[Germany]]) | cable chan 2 = Channel 714 | cable serv 3 = Kabelkiosk ([[Germany]]) | cable chan 3 = Channel 137 (SD) Channel 799 (HD) | cable serv 4 = CAIW ([[Netherlands]]) | cable chan 4 = Channel 153 | adsl serv 1 = Hansenet ([[Germany]]) | adsl chan 1 = Channel 48 (Only night at the time to 21:00 And 01:00) | adsl serv 2 = [[Alice (TV channel)|Alice]] ([[Germany]]) | adsl chan 2 = Channel 2 (SD) Channel 102 (HD) | adsl serv 3 = [[Arcor (telecommunications)|Arcor]] ([[Germany]]) | adsl chan 3 = Channel 171 |}} '''Body in Balance''' (BiB) is a [[TV channel]] which broadcasts from London, UK. It was the UK's first health and wellbeing channel. It airs programming about [[yoga]], [[pilates]], [[meditation]], [[health]] & [[Spirituality|spiritual]] well being. There are regional versions of the channel for [[Germany]] and [[Switzerland]], the [[Netherlands]] and [[Belgium]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Serbia]] and, more recently, [http://www.bodyinbalance.gr Greece]. In 2014, the channel plans to launch an online video on demand service. ==Background== Customers and prospects Body in Balance was established in 2005 as a German-language channel. An English-language version, the UK's first leisure and health channel, followed in 2007. The channels were founded in response to the increasing popularity of yoga in both countries. Since 2008 the channel's European network has grown from four to 30. The UK version was broadcast in the UK, Ireland, and 12 other countries in Europe and south east Asia. The UK version was removed from Sky channel 275 on 13 February 2012 and its satellite feed on [[Eutelsat 28A]] also ceased broadcasting. In November 2011, Body In Balance entered [[Administration of business|administration]], with the channel to be sold as a going concern.{{cite web|url=http://www.business-sale.com/news/article/buyers-sought-for-body-in-balance-tv-channel-35562.html|title=Buyers sought for Body in Balance TV channel|publisher=Business Sale Report|date=18 November 2011}} [[Chief operating officer]], Gerald Smith, left the company after concerns were raised over his employment despite being banned from acting as a [[Director (business)|director]] until 2021.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/mediatechnologyandtelecoms/media/8865652/Convicted-fraudster-Gerald-Smith-admits-media-company-Body-in-Balance-close-to-collapse.html|title=Convicted fraudster Gerald Smith admits media company Body in Balance 'close to collapse'|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|date=3 November 2011}} The company was purchased in November 2011 by Alfra TV Ltd and continues to broadcast in over 20 countries worldwide. As of 2014, Body in Balance is now owned by Body in Balance Networks and continues to be grow. ==Audience== Body in Balance describes itself as 'Europe's leading wellness and yoga channel'. The channel has 10 million viewers internationally, across 19 countries and 26 platforms. In the UK and worldwide, a large proportion of the channel's audience are professionals with an enthusiasm for health and fitness. The channel estimates that in the UK alone there are 9 million professional women with an enthusiasm for fitness, and has announced its intention to further focus on this demographic for future expansion. ==Teachers== The channel has worked with a number of notable teachers and instructors. Their yoga instructors include Maya Fiennes and Shiva Rea. Lynne Robinson, described by [[The Times]] as 'the Queen of pilates' has also taught for the channel, as has Doug Robertson, who is known for his ''Perfect Bum'' series. Wellness artists who have worked with Body in Balance include Danielle Collins, Lara Baumann and Ramona Braganza. The channel also works with a number of experts in the field of diet and wellness including Maryon Stewart, who pioneered the field on non-drug medicine in Australia. ==Programming== The company has a back catalogue consisting of over 400 hours of material. They license programmes and programme packages to producers throughout the world; recently the channel has made large sales in India and China. The program details. * has to do with * used * have Balance * that Yoga * good jobs Body * The Cooking * Give Hair * baby yoga * Music video * Good national ===Production=== As well as commissioning and acquiring programmes, the channel is increasingly involved in producing them and has in-house producers and post production facilities ===DVD distribution=== Body in Balance has a DVD library of over 40 titles and releases two new ones each month. In the UK, the channel sells to high street stores and supermarkets through [[Sanyo Broadcasting|RSK]], a major distributor. The channel also sells DVDs from its website shop, and on Amazon and other major online shops. In Germany, they have an agreement with [[Rough Trade Records|Rough Trade]], a major retailer. In the US, Body in Balance products appear on Amazon.com ==Events== The channel has been a media partner to a number of health and fitness events in the UK and America. In 2010 they were a partner to Yoga on the Lawn in New York. 10,000 people attended the event in [[Central Park]]. In 2011 the channel will be an official media partner to the [[Wanderlust Festival]], a festival of yoga and music held in various locations across the U.S.A. In the UK, the channel was a media partner to the Vitality Show, which took place at the [[Earl's Court]] exhibition centre in West London. The event was marketed as 'the ultimate girls day out'. This summer, Body in Balance is holding a Summer Solstice Yoga Workshops with Shiva Rea in [[Zoological Society of London|ZSL]] [[London Zoo]]. ==Satellites== Body In Balance operates two satellite feeds. [[Eutelsat]]'s [[Eutelsat 9A|9A]] delivers to Europe and Eastern Europe in German. In 2010 the company started broadcasting on [[Chinasat]], which currently delivers to Taiwan and the Pacific in Mandarin. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.bodyinbalance.tv/ Official website] [[Category:Satellite television]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2008]]

revision.text:
The '''Court of Assize''', ({{lang-nl|Hof van Assisen}}, {{lang-fr|Cour d'Assises}}) in [[Belgium]] is very similar to the [[Cour d'assises|French court]] of the same name. It has jurisdiction over all [[Felony|felonies]]{{clarify|date=February 2012}}<!-- a felony is a specific kind of common law offence. Should this say "serious offence"? --> that have not been correctionalised,{{clarify|date=February 2012}}<!-- this is not an English word, what does it mean?? --> over political offences and press-related offences, except those inspired by [[racism]] or [[xenophobia]], and over crimes of [[international law]], such as [[genocide]] and [[crime against humanity]]. These courts sit in each of the ten [[Provinces of Belgium|provinces]] and in the [[Arrondissement of Brussels-Capital|Brussels capital territory]]. Unlike the other courts, which have a permanent structure, a Court of Assize has to be constituted for each specific case. It comprises three professional judges and 12 [[Jury|jurors]].
The presiding judge is to be a judge at a [[Court of Appeal (Belgium)|Court of Appeal]] and is assisted by two judges of [[Court of First Instance (Belgium)|Courts of First Instance]]. The jury invariably consists of twelve members, who are balloted out of the citizens having the right to vote at elections and ageing between thirty and sixty, and they must be able to read and write. In addition, it is possible to call up one to twelve alternate jurors. Only the jury decides upon the facts, and with the judges the penalty is determined. There is no appeal for the verdicts, apart from one before the [[Court of Cassation (Belgium)|Court of Cassation]].<ref> {{cite web |title=Overview of the Belgian Law ''(implied title)'' |url=http://www.crimen.be/doc/inlrecht.doc |publisher=Circle of the Criminological Sciences department, Faculty of Law, [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven]] |format=doc |accessdate=2007-08-19}}</ref>
Mainly handling murder cases, it is the only court constitutionally authorized to judge [[delicts]] regarding the [[freedom of the press]] – though few practical cases have been considered to involve an infliction on that freedom and thus nearly all incidents were tried by lower courts.<ref> {{cite web |title=Mediaverslaggeving en de toegekende strafmaat: een verband? ''(thesis)'' |author1=Lenaerts, Nathalie |author2=promotor: Prof. Roe |author3=assessor: De Cock, R |publisher=Faculty of Social Sciences, [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven]] |url=http://www.statbel.fgov.be/studies/ac329_nl.pdf |format=pdf |accessdate=2007-08-19}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Judiciary of Belgium]] *[[War Crimes Law (Belgium)]] *[[Cour d'assises]] *[[Assizes]]
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Judiciary of Belgium|Assize]]

'''DJA FM 96.9''' is a [[Chad|Chadian]] [[Radio broadcasting|radio station]]. Established in 1998, this was the first privately owned radio station in [[Ndjamena]], [[Chad]]. Its president is Zara Yacoub. DJA is a non-specialized radio with an orientation towards the young people and women. The programming consists of news, magazines and interactive transmissions, in French and local Arabic over 60 hours a week.
==See also== * [[Media of Chad]] *[[List of radio stations in Africa]]
==References== *[http://www.ifex.org/20fr/layout/set/print/content/view/full/63855/ "Country's oldest privately owned radio station suspended, faces possible closure"]. ''[[Reporters sans frontières]]''. Accessed on 4 October 2007. *[http://www.panosparis.org/fichierProdGB/fichierProd1368.pdf ''Africentr@lemedias Newsletter''], Number 31, February 2005]. Institute Panos Paris. Accessed on 4 October 2007. *[http://www.freemedia.at/cms/ipi/freedom_detail.html?country=/KW0001/KW0004/KW0090/&year=2005 ''2005 World Press Freedom Review (Chad)'']. [[International Press Institute]]. Accessed on 4 October 2007.
==External links== *{{fr icon}} [http://fr.radio.oneworld.net/contact/company/view/10192 OneWorld Radiofrancais company information] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070717074012/http://ndjamena.usembassy.gov/radio_stations.html Radio Stations in Ndjamena, Chad]. US Embassy website.

{{Infobox scientist | name = Diane McKnight | image =CottonGlacier-Diane_McKnight.jpg | image_size =250 | caption =Diane McKnight in the [[McMurdo Dry Valleys]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|3|22}} | nationality = USA | fields =[[Limnology]]
[[Biogeochemistry]] | workplaces = [[University of Colorado Boulder]] | alma_mater = [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] | known_for = | awards =[[Fellow, American Association for the Advancement of Science]] | website = [https://instaar.colorado.edu/people/diane-m-mcknight/ Diane McKnight at CU-Boulder] }} '''Diane McKnight''' (born March 22, 1953) is a Professor of [[Civil engineering|Civil]], [[Environmental engineering|Environmental]], and [[Architectural engineering|Architectural Engineering]] at the [[University of Colorado – Boulder|University of Colorado Boulder]] and a Fellow at the [[Institute of Arctic and Alpine Research]] (INSTAAR).{{Cite web|url=https://instaar.colorado.edu/people/diane-m-mcknight/|title=Diane M. McKnight INSTAAR|website=instaar.colorado.edu|publisher=University of Colorado Boulder|access-date=2016-06-09}} McKnight is a founding Principal Investigator of the [[National Science Foundation|National Science Foundation’s]] [[Long Term Ecological Research Network|Long-Term Ecological Research]] (LTER) program in the [[McMurdo Dry Valleys]].{{Cite web|url=http://nsf.gov/discoveries/disc_summ.jsp?cntn_id=137309|title=Colorado high peaks losing glaciers as climate warms|date=2016|website=nsf.gov|publisher=[[National Science Foundation]]|access-date=2016-06-09}} == Early life and education == McKnight received a BS in Mechanical Engineering (1975), MS in Civil Engineering (1978), and her PhD in Environmental Engineering in 1979, all from [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.colorado.edu/ceae/diane-marie-mcknight|title=Civil, Environmental and Architectural Engineering|website=colorado.edu|publisher=University of Colorado Boulder|access-date=2016-06-09}} == Career and impact == After completing her graduate studies, McKnight began working for the [[United States Geological Survey|US Geological Survey]] (USGS) as a Research Scientist for the Water Resources Division.{{Cite book|title=Corps of Engineers Water Resources Infrastructure: Deterioration, Investment, or Divestment?|last=Committee on US Army Corps of Engineers Water Resources Science, Engineering, and Planning|first=|publisher=[[The National Academies Press]]|year=2012|isbn=|location=Washington, D.C|pages=}} As part of her work with USGS, she conducted research on lakes in the blast zone of [[Mount St. Helens]] in 1980.{{Cite web|url=https://connections.cu.edu/stories/five-questions-diane-mcknight|title=Five questions for Diane McKnight|last=Pasquale|first=Cynthia|date=2012-06-21|website=connections.cu.edu|access-date=2016-06-09}} In 1996, McKnight transitioned to the University of Colorado – Boulder, where she became one of the founding Principal Investigators of the McMurdo Dry Valleys Long Term Ecological Research Program{{Cite web|url=http://www.mcmlter.org/principal-investigators|title=Principal Investigators|website=www.mcmlter.org|publisher=McMurdo Dry Valleys LTER|access-date=2016-06-09}} in Antarctica’s [[McMurdo Dry Valleys]]. While continuing to conduct extensive research in [[Antarctica]], she also conducts research in the [[Rocky Mountains]],{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/3991302/colorado-waste-water-spill/|title=What The Colorado Waste Water Spill Tells Us About Mining Contamination|last=Worl|first=Justin|website=TIME.com|access-date=2016-06-09}} where she develops interactions with state and local groups involved in mine drainage and watershed issues. In total McKnight has authored or co-authored over 300 publications.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mcmlter.org/people/diane-mcknight|title=Diane Mcknight|website=mcmlter.org|publisher=McMurdo Dry Valleys LTER|access-date=2016-06-09}} McKnight has been nationally and internationally recognized for her “seminal”{{Cite web|url=http://www.egu.eu/awards-medals/john-dalton/2015/diane-mcknight/|title=John Dalton Medal|date=2015|website=European Geosciences Union|language=|access-date=2016-06-09}} and “visionary”{{Cite web|url=http://honors.agu.org/sfg-awardees/mcknight-receives-2014-hydrologic-sciences-award/|title=McKnight Receives 2014 Hydrologic Sciences Award|date=2015-04-09|website=honors.agu.org|publisher=[[American Geophysical Union]]|language=|access-date=2016-06-09}} contributions to Antarctic science. Her contributions to major scientific institutions include service on several National Research Council Committees; service on the Water, Science and Technology Board and the Polar Research Board; and tenure as President of the [[American Geophysical Union]] Biogeosciences section. In 2015 she was awarded CU-Boulder’s Distinguished Research Lectureship, which the university cites as being “among the highest honors bestowed by the faculty upon a faculty member at CU-Boulder”. McKnight also was founding editor of the ''[[Journal of Geophysical Research|Journal of Geophysical Research: Biogeosciences]].'' == Awards and honors == * John Dalton Medal, [[European Geosciences Union]], 2015 * Distinguished Research Lectureship, [[CU-Boulder]], 2015{{Cite web|url=http://www.colorado.edu/ceae/2015/05/14/mcknight-deliver-2015-distinguished-research-lecture-oct-29|title=McKnight to deliver Distinguished Research Lecture|date=2015|website=www.colorado.edu|publisher=University of Colorado Boulder|access-date=2016-06-09}} * Hydrologic Science Award, [[American Geophysical Union]], 2014 * Elected Member, [[National Academy of Engineering]], 2012{{Cite web|url=https://www.nae.edu/56106.aspx|title=Professor Diane M. McKnight|date=2012|website=www.nae.edu|publisher=[[National Academy of Engineering]]|access-date=2016-06-09}} * [[Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science]], 2009{{Cite web|url=http://www.colorado.edu/news/releases/2009/12/17/three-cu-boulder-faculty-members-elected-aaas-fellows-2009|title=Three CU-Boulder Faculty Members Elected AAAS Fellows for 2009|date=2009-12-17|website=News Center|access-date=2016-06-09}} * Walter B. Langbein Lectureship, American Geophysical Union, 2005{{Cite web|url=http://hydrology.agu.org/awards/langbein-lecture/|title=Langbein Lecture - Hydrology|website=hydrology.agu.org|publisher=American Geophysical Union|language=|access-date=2016-06-09}} * Fellow, American Geophysical Union, 2004{{Cite web|url=http://honors.agu.org/fellows/?name-2=McKnight&fellow_year-2=0§ionfocus_group-2=0&institution=&country=0&l=%25252Ffellows%25252F&fellows_directory=1&simian_search=1&fellows_directory_paged=1|title=Union Fellows|date=2015-03-23|website=honors.agu.org|publisher=American Geophysical Union|language=|access-date=2016-06-09}} * Meritorious Service Award, [[U.S. Geological Survey]], 1995 == Selected works == * McKnight, Diane M., et al. "Spectrofluorometric characterization of dissolved organic matter for indication of precursor organic material and aromaticity."''Limnology and Oceanography'' 46.1 (2001): 38-48. * Aiken, George R., et al. ''Humic substances in soil, sediment, and water: geochemistry, isolation and characterization''. John Wiley & Sons, 1985. * Tranvik, Lars J., et al. "Lakes and reservoirs as regulators of carbon cycling and climate." ''Limnology and Oceanography'' 54.6part2 (2009): 2298-2314. == References == {{Reflist|35em}} == External links == * [https://instaar.colorado.edu/people/diane-m-mcknight/ Diane McKnight's webpage] * [https://scholar.google.co.za/scholar?hl=en&as_sdt=0,5&q=diane+mcknight Diane McKnight] on [[Google scholar]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McKnight, Diane}} [[Category:American women scientists]] [[Category:1953 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Colorado Boulder faculty]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:United States Geological Survey personnel]] [[Category:Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:Women Antarctic scientists]]

{{more footnotes|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox former country |conventional_long_name = Duchy of Amalfi |common_name = Duchy of Amalfi |religion=[[Christianity]], [[History of the Jews in Campania and Basilicata|Judaism]] |continent = Europe |region = Italy |country = Italy |era = Middle Ages |status = Independent state |government_type = Duchy |year_start = 958 |year_end = 1137 |event_start = Duke elected |event_end = Sacked by [[Republic of Pisa|Pisa]] |p1 = Duchy of Naples |flag_p1 = |s1 = Kingdom of Sicily |flag_s1 = Bandiera del Regno di Sicilia 4.svg |image_flag = |motto = Descendit ex patribus romanorum |image_map = Italy 1000 AD.svg |image_map_caption = Italy, and the Duchy of Amalfi (a small state in bright yellow), at the close of the tenth century. |capital = Amalfi |latd=40 |latm=38 |latNS=N |longd=14 |longm=36 |longEW=E |common_languages = [[Greek language|Greek]], [[Neapolitan language|Neapolitan]] |leader1 = [[Manso I of Amalfi]] |year_leader1 = 966–1004 |title_leader = [[Dukes of Amalfi|Duke]] |stat_year1 = 1131 |stat_area1 = |stat_pop1 = 70000 |today = {{flag|Italy}} |footnotes = |currency=[[Solidus (coin)|solidus]]
[[Tarì]] }} The '''Duchy of Amalfi''' ({{lang-it|Ducato di Amalfi}}, {{Lang-la|Ducatus Amalphitanus}}) or the '''Republic of Amalfi''' ({{lang-it|Repubblica di Amalfi|links=no}}) was a ''[[de facto]]'' independent state centered on the [[Southern Italy|Southern Italian]] city of [[Amalfi]] during the 10th and 11th centuries. The city and its territory were originally part of the larger ''[[ducatus Neapolitanus]]'', governed by a [[Patrician (post-Roman Europe)|patrician]], but it extracted itself from [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] vassalage and first elected a [[dux|duke]] (or [[doge]]) in 958. During the 10th and 11th centuries Amalfi was estimated to have a population of 50,000 -70,000 people.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/45102891|title=The riddle of the compass : the invention that changed the world|last=D.|first=Aczel, Amir|date=2001|publisher=Harcourt|isbn=0151005060|edition= 1st|location=New York|oclc=45102891}} It rose to become an economic powerhouse, a commercial center whose merchants dominated [[Mediterranean]] and [[Italy|Italian]] trade for a century before being surpassed and superseded by the other [[maritime republics]] of [[Northern Italy|the North]], like [[Republic of Pisa|Pisa]], [[Republic of Venice|Venice]], and [[Republic of Genoa|Genoa]]. In 1073, Amalfi lost its independence and fell to the [[Normans]], from whose yoke it failed in two separate attempts to free itself. ==History== The city of Amalfi was founded as a trading post in 339. Its first bishop was appointed in 596. In 838, the city was captured by [[Sicard of Benevento]] with help from traitors within the city, who led him in through the waterward defenses. Many of the Amalfitans in [[Salerno]] sacked that city and left. In 839, Amalfi freed itself from [[Lombards|Lombard]] domination and elected a [[prefect]]. Nearby [[Atrani]] participated in these early prefectural elections. Subsequently, Amalfi helped to free [[Siconulf]] to oppose the ruling [[Prince of Benevento]]. In 897, the self-governing republic, still nominally tied to the Byzantine Empire, was defeated in a war with [[Duchy of Sorrento|Sorrento]], supported by [[Duchy of Naples|Naples]], in which her prefect was captured, later ransomed. In 914, the prefect [[Mastalus I of Amalfi|Mastalus I]] was appointed first [[judge]]. In 903 the Amalfitans joined forces with Naples to attack the Arabs that had established them selves on the banks of the [[Garigliano|Garigliano river]].{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/30112695|title=Family power in southern Italy : the duchy of Gaeta and its neighbours, 850-1139|last=1965-|first=Skinner, Patricia,|date=1995|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=052146479X|location=Cambridge|oclc=30112695}} However the combined forces of Amalfi and the Naples were driven back by the Arabs and their allies, the Italian city state of [[Gaeta]]. In 915 Amalfi did not join the [[Battle of Garigliano]] to fight against the Arabs. This was most likely due to the fact that since 909 Amalfi had been heavily trading with the [[Fatimid Caliphate]] and did not want to jeopardize relations with this powerful trade partner. In 958, [[Mastalus II of Amalfi|Mastalus II]] was assassinated and [[Sergius I of Amalfi|Sergius I]] was elected first [[dux|duke]] (or [[doge]]). From 981 to 983, Amalfi ruled the [[Principality of Salerno]]. In 987, the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Amalfi-Cava de' Tirreni|Amalfitan bishopric]] was raised to archiepiscopal status. From 1034, Amalfi came under the control of the [[Principality of Capua]] and, in 1039, that of Salerno. In 1073, [[Robert Guiscard]] conquered the city and took the title ''dux Amalfitanorum'': "duke of the Amalfitans." In 1096, Amalfi revolted, but this was put down in 1101. It revolted again in 1130 and was finally subdued in 1131, when the [[John (Sicilian admiral)|Emir John]] marched on Amalfi by land and [[George of Antioch]] blockaded the town by sea and set up a base on [[Capri]]. In 1135 and 1137, Pisa sacked the city and the glory of Amalfi was past. The Arab traveller [[Ibn Hawqal]], writing in 977 during the great reign of [[Manso I of Amalfi|Manso I]], described Amalfi as: {{cquote |''. . . la più prospera città di Longobardia, la più nobile, la più illustre per le sue condizioni, la più agiata ed opulenta. Il territorio di Amalfi confina con quello di Napoli; la quale è bella città, ma meno importante di Amalfi. . . . the most prosperous Lombard city, the most noble, the most illustrious for its conditions, the most wealthy and opulent. The territory of Amalfi borders that of Naples; a beautiful city, but less important than Amalfi.}} The title "Duke of Amalfi" was revived in the later 14th century as a title used within the [[Kingdom of Naples]]. [[Henry Wadsworth Longfellow]] wrote these lines in a poem{{Cite web|url=http://www.hwlongfellow.org/poems_poem.php?pid=204|title=Longfellow: Amalfi, Masque of Pandora and Other Poems|website=www.hwlongfellow.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-01}} titled Amalfi in 1869.{{Cite book|title=Abbot Desiderius and the Ties Between Montecassino and Amalfi in the Eleventh Century|last=Willard|first=Henry M.|publisher=Montecassino|year=1973|isbn=|location=|pages=}} Where are now the freighted barks From the marts of east and west? Where the knights in iron sarks Journeying to the Holy Land, Where the merchants with their wares, And their gallant brigantines Vanished like a fleet of cloud, Like a passing trumpet-blast, Are those splendors of the past, And the commerce and the crowd! The poem is about medieval Amalfi. and it references the crusades and its important maritime history. == Importance == After the Amalfitans broke free of Lombard control they did not return to Neapolitan control but instead stated their independence. After 839 Amalfi was an independent entity and created a strong maritime presence. Amalfi had strong ties with both the [[Byzantine Empire]] and the [[Fatimid Caliphate]].{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1007067413|title=Conflict, commerce, and an aesthetic of appropriation in the Italian maritime cities, 1000-1150|last=R.,|first=Mathews, Karen|isbn=9789004335653|location=Leiden|oclc=1007067413}} The Amalfitans had a permanent and important presence in [[Constantinople]] during the 10th and 11th centuries. Amalfitans also created Latin Christian outposts in the [[Levant]] around 1040 and hostels for Christian pilgrims in [[Jerusalem]] and [[Antioch]]. During the 10th and 11th centuries Amalfi was dominating trade and commerce with North Africa and the Levant,{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/828621064|title=Medieval Italy : texts in translation|date=2009|publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press|others=Jansen, Katherine Ludwig, 1957-, Drell, Joanna H., 1965-, Andrews, Frances.|isbn=0812206061|location=Philadelphia|oclc=828621064}} and one of the major exports from Amalfi during the Middle Ages was the [[chestnut]].{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/671307987|title=Ecologies and economies in medieval and early modern Europe : studies in environmental history for Richard C. Hoffmann|date=2010|publisher=Brill|others=Bruce, Scott G. (Scott Gordon), 1967-|isbn=9789047444572|location=Boston|oclc=671307987}} == The legacy of the Duchy of Amalfi == [[File:Amalfi2.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Amalfi2.jpg|thumb|Statute of ''Flavio Gioia'' in Amalfi by [[Alfonso Balzico]], 1900]]While The Duchy of Amalfi never regained its independence after 1137 the city of Amalfi was still important to maritime trade for the next 200 years until 1343 when an earthquake and a storm destroyed most of its harbor. Probably the most important contribution Amalfi made during those 200 years before its harbor was destroyed was the perfection of the modern day box [[compass]]. Between 1295 and 1302 the [[Flavio Gioja|Flavio Gioia]] turned the compass from a needle floating in water to what we use today, a round box with a compass card that rotates 360 degrees attached to a magnetic element. ==See also== * [[Dukes of Amalfi]] * [[Amalfi Coast]] * [[Maritime republics]] ==Bibliography== {{refbegin}} * {{cite book|last=Pavan|first=Massimiliano|title=Dizionario Biografico degli Italiani|year=1960|publisher=Istituto della Enciclopedia italiana}} * {{cite book|last=Skinner|first=Patricia|authorlink=Patricia Skinner (historian)|title=Family Power in Southern Italy: The Duchy of Gaeta and Its Neighbours, 850-1139|year=1995|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|location=[[London]]|isbn=0-521-52205-6}} * {{cite book|last=Norwich|first=John Julius|title=The Normans in the South, 1016-1130|year=1967|publisher=[[Longman]]|location=[[London]]|authorlink=John Julius Norwich}} * {{cite book|last=Norwich|first=John Julius|title=The Normans in the South 1016-1130|year=1970|publisher=[[Longman]]|location=[[London]]|authorlink=John Julius Norwich}} * {{cite book|last=Curtis|first=Edmund|title=Roger of Sicily and the Normans in Lower Italy, 1016-1154|year=1912|publisher=G. P. Putnam's Sons|location=[[New York City|New York]]}} * {{cite book|last=Donald|first=Matthew|title=The Norman kingdom of Sicily|year=1992|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|location=[[London]]|isbn=0-521-26911-3}} * {{cite book|last=Houben|first=Hubert|title=Roger II of Sicily: a ruler between East and West|year=2002|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|location=[[London]]|isbn=0-521-65573-0}} * {{cite book|last=Chalandon|first=Ferdinand|title=Histoire de la domination normande en Italie et en Sicile|year=1907|publisher=Librairie A. Picard et fils|location=[[Paris]]|authorlink=Ferdinand Chalandon|language=French}} {{refend}} {{Former monarchies Italian peninsula}} {{Repubbliche Marinare}} {{coord missing|Italy}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Duchy of Amalfi| ]] [[Category:City-states]] [[Category:Amalfi Coast]] [[Category:Former countries on the Italian Peninsula]] [[Category:Former duchies|Amalfi]] [[Category:Maritime republics]] [[Category:History of Campania]] [[Category:Norman conquest of southern Italy]] [[Category:10th century in Italy]] [[Category:11th century in Italy]] [[Category:States and territories established in the 950s]] [[Category:1073 disestablishments]] [[Category:958 establishments]] [[Category:10th-century establishments in Italy]] [[Category:1070s disestablishments in Europe]] [[Category:11th-century disestablishments in Italy]]

revision.text:
'''G-15''' is a name given to a group in [[Eritrea]] that opposes the policy of President [[Isaias Afewerki]] postponing elections and their failure in implementing the constitution. The membership of this group consists of former members of the President's ruling [[People's Front for Democracy and Justice]] (PFDJ) which has ruled the country since its independence in 1993. In May 2001 the group issued an open letter raising criticism against Isayas Afeworki's actions calling them "illegal and unconstitutional."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.hrw.org/en/node/82280/section/6 |title=Service for Life |publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]] |page=6 of 12|date=16 April 2009 |accessdate=2 January 2009}}</ref>
Of the 15 members of the group, 11 are imprisoned, three are now living in the [[United States]] and the last remaining one, Muhammad Berhan Belata, had left the group and rejoined the government. The 11 members who are imprisoned are thought to be charged with treason. The Central Office of the PFDJ believes that they share, "...a common guilt: at the minimum, abdication of responsibility during Eritrea's difficult hours, at the maximum, grave conspiracy."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200109260023.html |title=Eritrea: Party Puts its Case Against Dissidents |publisher=allAfrica.com |author=Charles Cobb, Jr. |date=26 September 2001 |accessdate=2006-09-02}}</ref> [[Amnesty International]] named the imprisoned 11 [[prisoners of conscience]] and called for their immediate release.<ref name="AI">{{cite news |title=Eritrea: Prisoners of conscience held for a decade must be released|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/eritrea-prisoners-conscience-held-decade-must-be-released-2011-09-15 |publisher=Amnesty International |date=15 September 2011 |accessdate=26 December 2011}}</ref>
The list of the G-15<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.unhcr.org/cgi-bin/texis/vtx/home/opendoc.pdf?tbl=RSDCOI&id=447aa7904 |title=Born powerful? Post-Liberation Politics in Eritrea and Zimbabwe |publisher=UNHCR |first=Sara |last=Dorman |accessdate=2006-06-11}}</ref> includes: * [[Petros Solomon]] * [[Mahmoud Ahmed Sherifo]] * [[Haile Woldense]] * [[Mesfin Hagos]] * [[Ogbe Abraha]] * [[Hamid Himid]] * [[Saleh Idris Kekya]] * [[Estifanos Seyoum]] * [[Berhane Ghebrezgabiher]] * [[Astier Fesehazion]] * [[Mohammed Berhan Blata]] * [[Germano Nati]] * [[Beraki Gebreselassie]] * [[Adhanom Ghebremariam]] * [[Mahamoud Ahmed]]
==References== <references />
==External links== *[[Amnesty International]]: [https://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/AFR64/008/2002 Eritrea: Arbitrary detentions of government critics and journalists]
{{Eritrea-stub}}
[[Category:Politics of Eritrea]]

{{Infobox company | name = Groupe Bigard | logo = | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 1968 | founder = [[Jean-Paul Bigard]] | defunct = | location_city = [[Quimperlé]] | location_country = [[France]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = | products = | production = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.bigard.fr www.bigard.fr] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Groupe Bigard''' is a French meat processing company. It owns half of all [[slaughterhouse]]s in France It processes beef, mutton, and pork. Its best-known brandname in Charal.
==Overview== The company was founded as ''Société commerciale des viandes'' by [[Jean-Paul Bigard]] in 1968.<ref name="bloomberg">[https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=5490745 Company Overview of Groupe Bigard SA], ''Bloomberg Business''</ref> It became known as Groupe Bigard six years later, in 1974.<ref name="bloomberg"/>
The company is headquartered in [[Quimperlé]], France.<ref name="bloomberg"/> It owns half of all slaughterhouses in France.<ref name="lesechosmarie">Marie-Josee Cougard, [http://www.lesechos.fr/journal20150724/lec2_industrie_et_services/021224462029-les-abattoirs-un-secteur-concentre-et-domine-par-le-groupe-bigard-1139488.php Les abattoirs, un secteur concentré et dominé par le groupe Bigard], ''Les Echos'', July 24, 2015</ref> It sells meat under the brandnames of Charal, D'Anvial, Tendre et Plus, and Shems.<ref name="lesechosmarie"/> Its best-known brandname is Charal.<ref name="lesechosmarie"/>
As of 2015, Jean-Paul Bigard owns 90% of the company,<ref name="capitalbigard">[http://www.capital.fr/a-la-une/classement-des-francais-les-plus-riches/fiches/jean-paul-bigard-943390 Jean-Paul Bigard (Groupe Bigard)], ''Capital'', June 23, 2014</ref> with an estimated wealth of 350 million Euros.<ref name="challengesbigard">[http://www.challenges.fr/classements/fortune/fiche/jean-paul-bigard-et-sa-famille;65.html Jean-Paul Bigard et sa famille]</ref> He serves as the President of the Syndicat National de l'Industrie des Viandes (SNIV) and the [[Syndicat National du Commerce du Porc]] (SNCP).<ref name="lesechosmarie"/>
==2015 French pork production crisis== In August 2015, both Groupe Bigard and its competitor, [[Cooperl Arc Atlantique]], refused to accept the price set at the [[Marché du Porc Breton]] in [[Plérin]], which is used as the norm across France, on the basis that it was too high in comparison with the price set by other European countries like Germany, where both companies also sell pork.<ref name="lefigvictoria">Victoria Masson, [http://www.lefigaro.fr/conjoncture/2015/08/11/20002-20150811ARTFIG00049-deux-importants-industriels-de-la-viande-boycottent-le-porc-francais.php Deux importants industriels de la viande boycottent le porc français], ''Le Figaro'', August 11, 2015</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bigard, Groupe}} [[Category:Food and drink companies established in 1968]] [[Category:Companies based in Brittany]] [[Category:Meat companies of France]] [[Category:1968 establishments in France]] {{France-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Montenegro}} "Just Get Out of My Life" | image = [[File:Andrea Demirović - Just Get Out of My Life.JPG|180px]] | caption = | year = 2009 | country = Montenegro | artist = [[Andrea Demirović]] | as = | with = | language = English | languages = | composer = [[Ralph Siegel (songwriter)|Ralph Siegel]] | lyricist = [[Bernd Meinunger]],
José Juan Santana Rodríguez | place = | points = | place_semi = 11th | points_semi = 44 | prev = Zauvijek volim te | prev_link = Zauvijek volim te | next = Euro Neuro | next_link = Euro Neuro | next_year = 2012 }} '''"Just Get Out of My Life"''' is a song by [[Andrea Demirović]] and was the [[Montenegro|Montenegrin]] entry to the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2009]], held in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]]. This was the first [[English language]] Montenegrin entry at Eurovision, as well as the first time the country was represented by a female soloist."EUROSONG 2009", [[Radio Television of Montenegro]], 2009-01-23{{cite web |url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/66M7wX5UM?url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/13012 |archivedate=2012-03-22 |title=Montenegro: Andrea Demirovic to Eurovision |last=Klier |first=Marcus |date=2009-01-23 |publisher=''ESCToday'' |accessdate=2009-01-23 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=4894|title=Montenegro: Andrea Demirovic to Moscow!|last=van Tongeren|first=Mario|date=2009-01-23|publisher=''Oikotimes''|accessdate=2009-01-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216090058/http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=4894|archivedate=2009-02-16|df=}} The song however failed to reach the final. In the first days, the names of the song's authors were held as a secret by [[RTCG]]. They were later revealed to be veteran German Eurovision composers [[Ralph Siegel (songwriter)|Ralph Siegel]] and [[Bernd Meinunger]], along with [[José Juan Santana Rodríguez]].{{discogs release|1905945|Eurovision Song Contest Moscow 2009 (CD credits)}} The song contains a sample from "Innocent Heart" sung by Ruth Portelli, which was also written by the same author and composer.{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=4932 |title=Montenegro: Ralph Siegel is back - 19th time! |date=2009-01-28 |publisher=''Oikotimes'' |accessdate=2009-01-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100206005113/http://oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=4932 |archivedate=2010-02-06 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=4937 |title=More on the Montenegrin songwriting mystery! |last=Rendall |first=Alasdair |date=2009-01-28 |publisher=''Oikotimes'' |accessdate=2009-01-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100206005241/http://oikotimes.com/v2/index.php?file=articles&id=4937 |archivedate=2010-02-06 |df= }} == Music video == The music video for the entry was filmed in a studio in [[Skopje]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]. It was directed by famous Balkan video director [[Dejan Miličević]], and it stars Andrea and a [[Serbia]]n male model called Vasa Nestorović. The video premiered on RTCG's website on 10 March. == Track listing == # Eurovision Version – 3:01 # Moscow Club Mix Version – 4:53 # Energy Radio Mix – 3:07 # Dance Version – 4:25 # Finger N Kadel Radio Mix – 3:42 # Finger N Kadel House Mix – 5:55 == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090313025430/http://rtcg.me/index.php/mozaik/evrovizija Eurovision Song Contest devoted page on RTCG's site] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Montenegro in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 2009}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of 2009]] [[Category:Eurovision songs of Montenegro]] [[Category:Songs written by Ralph Siegel]] [[Category:Songs written by Bernd Meinunger]] [[Category:2009 songs]] {{2000s-song-stub}} {{Montenegro-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Kukar''' family was a Croatian noble family, mentioned in the ''[[Pacta conventa (Croatia)|Pacta conventa]]'' as one of the twelve tribes of the [[Croatia in union with Hungary|Kingdom of Croatia]]. They are first mentioned in the second half of the 12th century, in the area of [[Podstrana]] (near Split), where the so called "Kukari territory" (''territorium Cucarorum)'' was located. They are mentioned also in the [[Supetar Cartulary|Supetar cartulary]] and it is also mentioned by Thomas the Archdeacon (1200'''–'''1268) in his chronicle ''[[Historia Salonitana]]''.
From the 15th century, they are mentioned to have been living in [[Skradin]] and its surroundings. The family was last mentioned in 1581.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.enciklopedija.hr/Natuknica.aspx?ID=34472|title=Kukari - Hrvatska enciklopedija|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>

The '''[[mass surveillance]] industry''' is a multibillion-dollar [[economic sector]] which has undergone phenomenal growth rates since 2001. According to [[data]] provided by ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', the retail market for surveillance tools has grown from "nearly zero" in 2001 to about US$5 billion in 2011.<ref>{{cite news|authors=Jennifer Valentino-Devries , [[Julia Angwin]] and Steve Stecklow|title=Document Trove Exposes Surveillance Methods|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970203611404577044192607407780|publisher=''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''|quote=Intelligence agencies in the U.S. and abroad have long conducted their own surveillance. But in recent years, a retail market for surveillance tools has sprung up from "nearly zero" in 2001 to about $5 billion a year, said [[Jerry Lucas]], president of TeleStrategies Inc., the show's operator.}}</ref> The size of the video surveillance market rose to US$13.5 billion in 2012, and is expected to reach US$39 billion by 2020.<ref name="fortunesurveillance">{{cite news|title=The great surveillance boom|url=http://management.fortune.cnn.com/2013/04/26/video-surveillance-boston-bombings/|accessdate=22 September 2013 | work=CNN}}</ref>
== Current developments == Fueled by widespread fears of terrorist attacks, the future of surveillance is particularly promising in the field of [[video content analysis]], where computers analyze live camera feeds to count the number of people, register [[temperature]] changes, and automatically identify suspicious behavior via [[statistic]]al [[algorithm]]s.<ref name="fortunesurveillance"/> The following terrorist attacks have led to a significant increase in street-level surveillance:
* Shortly after the 2013 [[Boston Marathon bombings]], police commissioner [[Edward F. Davis]] requested the installation of more [[cameras]] to boost street-level surveillance.<ref name="bbsurveilance1"/> The [[Mayor of New York City]], [[Michael Bloomberg]], said that the bombings are a "terrible reminder" of the importance of acquiring surveillance technology.<ref name="bbsurveilance1">{{cite web|last=Terry Atlas and Greg Stohr|title=Surveillance Cameras Sought by Cities After Boston Bombs|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2013-04-29/boston-bombing-spurs-demand-for-video-monitoring-decried-by-aclu|publisher=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]|accessdate=22 September 2013}}</ref> * In the aftermath of the 2001 [[September 11 attacks]], U.S. cities spent billions of dollars in federal [[counter-terrorism]] funding to deploy video sensors in public areas.<ref name="bbsurveilance1"/>
== Private intelligence agencies == {{Expand section|date=October 2013}} [[Private intelligence agency|Private intelligence agencies]] are non-governmental [[corporations]] involved in the collection and analysis of information. Prior to the 9/11 attacks, such tasks were mostly performed by governmental agencies such as the [[National Security Agency]] (NSA) and [[Central Intelligence Agency]] (CIA). After the 9/11 terrorist attacks, the gathering of intelligence was rapidly outsourced by the U.S. government to private intelligences agencies, which function as [[independent contractor]]s.<ref name="wapoprivint"/>
According to ''[[The Washington Post]]'', about one in four U.S. intelligence workers are contractors, and over 70 percent of the budget of the [[United States Intelligence Community]] is earmarked for payment to private firms.<ref name="wapoprivint">{{cite news|last=Robert O’Harrow Jr., Dana Priest and Marjorie Censer|title=NSA leaks put focus on intelligence apparatus’s reliance on outside contractors|url=https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-06-10/business/39873303_1_intelligence-agencies-intelligence-community-intelligence-analysts|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=22 September 2013|date=11 June 2013}}</ref> An examination by The Post found that 1,931 private companies work on programs related to intelligence in about 10,000 locations across the United States.<ref>{{cite news|last=Robert O’Harrow Jr.|title=The outsourcing of U.S. intelligence raises risks among the benefits|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/the-outsourcing-of-us-intelligence-raises-risks-among-the-benefits/2013/06/09/eba2d314-d14c-11e2-9f1a-1a7cdee20287_story.html|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=22 September 2013|date=10 June 2013}}</ref>
The average annual cost of a contract employee is US$250,000, almost twice that of a federal employee.<ref>{{cite news|last=Robert O'Harrow Jr.|title=Costs Skyrocket As DHS Runs Up No-Bid Contracts|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/06/27/AR2007062702988.html|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=22 September 2013|date=28 June 2007}}</ref>
=== Stratfor === {{further|2012–13 Stratfor email leak}}
Strategic Forecasting, Inc., more commonly known as [[Stratfor]], is a global intelligence company founded in 1996 in [[Austin, Texas]]. It offers information to governments and private clients including [[Dow Chemical Company]], [[Lockheed Martin]], [[Northrop Grumman]], [[Raytheon]], the [[United States Department of Homeland Security|U.S. Department of Homeland Security]], the [[Defense Intelligence Agency|U.S. Defense Intelligence Agency]], and the [[United States Marine Corps|U.S. Marine Corps]].<ref name="stratforguardian">{{cite web|last=Pratap Chatterjee|title=WikiLeaks' Stratfor dump lifts lid on intelligence-industrial complex|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/cifamerica/2012/feb/28/wikileaks-intelligence-industrial-complex|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=22 September 2013}}</ref>
In 2012–13, over 5 million internal [[e-mail]]s from [[Stratfor]] were released by [[WikiLeaks]].<ref name="stratforguardian" />
===Booz Allen Hamilton === [[File:Edward Snowden-2.jpg|thumb|From March to June 2013, [[Edward Snowden]] took a pay cut to work at [[Booz Allen Hamilton]] so that he could download additional [[top-secret]] documents.<ref>[http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/1268209/snowden-sought-booz-allen-job-gather-evidence-nsa-surveillance "Snowden sought Booz Allen job to gather evidence on NSA surveillance"], Lana Lam, ''South China Morning Post'', 25 June 2013. Retrieved 13 June 2015.</ref>]]
'''[[Booz Allen Hamilton]]''' is a [[publicly traded company]] that is majority-owned by [[The Carlyle Group]], a global [[asset management]] firm specializing in [[private equity]], based in [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name="wapo1booz">{{cite news|last=Thomas Heath and Marjorie Censer|title=NSA revelations put Booz Allen Hamilton, Carlyle Group in uncomfortable limelight|url=https://articles.washingtonpost.com/2013-06-11/business/39896957_1_carlyle-group-nsa-firm|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=22 September 2013|date=15 June 2013}}</ref> Founded in 1914 by [[Edwin G. Booz]], Booz Allen Hamilton became one of the most profitable private contractors by supplying tens of thousands of intelligence analysts to the U.S. federal government.<ref name="wapo1booz"/> During the [[fiscal year]] of 2013, Booz Allen Hamilton derived 99% of its income from the government, and the largest portion of its revenue (16%) came from the [[U.S. Army]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Neil Irwin|title=Seven facts about Booz Allen Hamilton|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/wonkblog/wp/2013/06/10/seven-facts-about-booz-allen-hamilton/|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref> Half of its employees carry [[Classified information in the United States|top secret security clearances]].<ref name=Sanger>Sanger, David E. and Nicole Perlroth. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/16/us/after-profits-defense-contractor-faces-the-pitfalls-of-cybersecurity.html?_r=0 After Profits, Defense Contractor Faces the Pitfalls of Cybersecurity]." ''[[The New York Times]]''. June 15, 2013. Retrieved on June 27, 2013.</ref> In the first half of 2013, Booz Allen Hamilton has won numerous contracts, including:
* A US$95 million contract with the [[Space and Naval Warfare Systems Command]]<ref name="dailybzh">{{cite web|last=Filipa Ioanno|title=Booz Allen Keeps Winning Government Security Contracts After Snowden Leak|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/08/15/booz-allen-keeps-winning-government-security-contracts-after-snowden-leak.html|publisher=''[[The Daily Beast]]''|accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref> * A US$102 million contract with the [[United States Department of Transportation|Department of Transportation]]<ref name="dailybzh"/> * A US$315 million contract with the [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency]]<ref name="dailybzh"/> * A US$900 million contract to strengthen [[cybersecurity]]<ref name="dailybzh"/> * A US$5.6 billion contract with the [[Defense Intelligence Agency]]<ref name="dailybzh"/> * A US$6 billion contract, shared with other companies, to develop a shopping hub for federal agencies looking to shield their computer networks from hackers.<ref>{{cite news|title=Booz Allen to Lockheed Win Part of $6 Billion Cyber Award|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-08-13/booz-allen-to-lockheed-win-part-of-6-billion-cyber-award.html|publisher=''[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]''|accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref>
In 2006, Booz Allen Hamilton was recognized by ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' magazine as one of the "100 Best Companies to Work For".<ref>{{cite news|title=100 Best Companies to Work For|url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/bestcompanies/snapshots/3938.html|publisher=''[[Fortune (magazine)]]''|accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref> In 2013, Booz Allen Hamilton was hailed by [[Bloomberg Businessweek]] as "the World's Most Profitable Spy Organization".<ref>{{cite web|title=Booz Allen, the World's Most Profitable Spy Organization|url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2013-06-20/booz-allen-the-worlds-most-profitable-spy-organization|publisher=''[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]''|accessdate=23 September 2013}}</ref>
==Controversy== Commercial mass surveillance often makes use of [[copyright]] laws and "[[clickwrap|user agreements]]" to obtain (typically uninformed) 'consent' to surveillance from consumers who use their software or other related materials. This allows gathering of information which would be technically illegal if performed by government agencies. This data is then often shared with government agencies - thereby - in practice - defeating the purpose of such privacy protections.
Reporters Without Borders' March 2013 ''Special report on Internet Surveillance'' contained a list of "Corporate Enemies of the Internet", companies that sell products that are liable to be used by governments to violate human rights and freedom of information. The five companies on the initial list were: [[Amesys]] (France), [[Blue Coat Systems]] (U.S.), [[FinFisher|Gamma]] (UK and Germany), [[Hacking Team]] (Italy), and Trovicor (Germany), but the list was not exhaustive and is likely to be expanded in the future.<ref name=RSFSRS-March2013>[http://surveillance.rsf.org/en/ ''The Enemies of the Internet Special Edition : Surveillance''], Reporters Without Borders, 12 March 2013</ref>
== See also == * [[Cyber-arms industry]] * [[Surveillance capitalism]] * [[Market for zero-day exploits]]
== References == {{reflist |30em}}

{{Infobox non-profit | name = Mending Kids | image = [[File:Mending Kids International Logo 2013.jpg|250px|Mending Kids International logo]] | type = [[NGO]] | founded_date = 2006 | registration_id = United States
(95-4394305) | founder = [http://www.mendingkids.org/history.php Cris Embleton] | location = 2307 West Olive Avenue, Suite B, Burbank, California, US | origins = | area_served = Worldwide | mission = to provide life-changing surgeries to children worldwide | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | non-profit_slogan = "HOPE LOVE MEND" | former name = | homepage = {{URL| http://www.mendingkids.org }} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''Mending Kids ''' is a [[501(c) organization|501(c)3 non-profit organization]] that provides surgeries to children across the world while training local medical communities to become self-sustaining. It brings surgical mission teams of doctors, nurses and volunteers who donate their time and services to travel to developing countries to perform procedures that range from [[pediatric]] open-heart, neuro, ENT, [[orthopedic]] or general surgeries on impoverished or orphaned children while establishing sustainable teaching programs. Since 2006, it has helped thousands of children in 54 countries around the world, including the United States.{{cite web |url=http://www.mendingkids.org/assets/pdf/HM_CaseStatement.pdf |title=MKI Hometown Mission facts and info sheet |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2013-12-04 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The organization currently operates in [[Burbank, California]]. == History == Cris Embleton started volunteering nearly 30 years ago by helping local hospitals and communities. After the death of her adopted daughter just prior to her first birthday, she started her own [[Non-profit Organization]] - 'Healing the Children',{{cite web|url=http://www.htcorwwa.org/Our-History.asp |title=History of Healing the Children |publisher=Htcorwwa.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-04}} which is now running in 14{{cite web|url=http://www.mendingkids.org/history.php |title=Our History — Mending Kids International. Hope. Love. Mend |publisher=Mendingkids.org |date= |accessdate=2013-12-04}} states. In order to expand the mission in California, Embleton and her local Board of Directors broke off from the organization and started Mending Kids International[http://www.signalscv.com/archives/728/ Mending hearts through Mending Kids], By Tammy Marashlian, The Santa Clarita Valley Signal in 2005. == Programs == :'''1)U.S. Surgeries''' –– The organization brings children with complex surgical needs to the United States for treatment in partnerships with hospitals such as –– [[Children's Hospital Los Angeles]], [[Cedars-Sinai Medical Center]] and [[UCLA Medical Center]] –– and several other medical organizations across Southern California.{{cite web |url=http://www.pasadenanow.com/main/a-mending-kids-international-gala-to-remember |title=A Mending Kids International Gala to Remember, By Franz A.D. Morales, Pasadena Now |publisher=Pasadenanow.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140325005259/http://www.pasadenanow.com/main/a-mending-kids-international-gala-to-remember |archivedate=2014-03-25 |df= }} During the surgeries, the organization places the children with approved host families who make certain the children's emotional needs and living arrangements are provided. :[[File:Mending Kids Tanzania Surgical Mission 2015.png|thumb|Mending Kids patient in Tanzania photographed by volunteer, Rebecca Pollack Parker.]]'''2)Surgical Missions''' –– Mending Kids assembles pediatric surgical mission teams along with non-medical volunteers and takes them to developing countries to provide free specialized surgeries to under-served, impoverished and/or orphaned children. Surgical missions provide help to children who would otherwise not have access to this care in their own country. The missions' priorities are to provide local surgeons and medical staff with mentoring and specialized surgical training in order to create self-sustainment. In 2014, MendingKids is scheduled to travel on 11 missions including: Ethiopia, Panama,Guatemala (2 trips), Mozambique, China, Peru, Costa Rica, Panama and Nicaragua. :'''3)International Surgeries''' –– Due to a variety of reasons, including funding, it may be near impossible to fly the child to Los Angeles or send a surgical mission team to serve one patient. To solve this type of cases, MendingKids arranges to fund or provide surgeries to these children locally or in neighboring countries by partnering with local hospitals and other NGOs who may have access to surgeons but not the necessary funding. :'''4) Hometown Mission''' Mending Kids launched their first Hometown mission in July 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.mendingkids.org/hometown-mission-2013.php |accessdate=March 24, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301110130/http://www.mendingkids.org/hometown-mission-2013.php |archivedate=March 1, 2014 }} The program gives needed operations to children living in the United States treatment when they do not have access to the surgical care they need, or have been denied by providers. A volunteer surgical team from a local hospital perform operations on up to 20 children on one day over the summer. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official|www.mendingkids.org}} * [http://vimeo.com/80112176/ Mending Kids Hometown Mission Clip] * {{imdb title|tt3516636|Mending Kids International: All Star Concert for Children Worldwide 2014}} [[Category:International medical and health organizations]] [[Category:International organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in California]] [[Category:Health charities in the United States]] [[Category:Organizations based in Los Angeles County, California]] {{nonprofit-org-stub}} {{int-org-stub}}

{{Infobox musical artist | name = Public Relations | image = Public Relations skupina 1.jpg | caption = Public Relations (2013) | landscape = Yes | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Ostrava]], [[Czech Republic]] | genre = [[Electronic rock]] | years_active = 2004 - present | website = {{URL|http://public.relations.cz}} | current_members = Jan Ražnok
Jiří Sosik
Tomáš Klos
Marek Konečný | past_members = Lukáš Kroutil
Tomáš Frieb
Lukáš Kraut
Tomáš Demel
et al. }} '''Public Relations''' is a [[Czech Republic|Czech]] [[Rock music|rock]] [[Band (music)|band]], which was formed in 2004.{{cite web | url = http://www.musicweb.cz/aktuality/public-relations-se-odrazeji-ode-dna-a-zacinaji-znovu | title = Public Relations se odrážejí ode dna a začínají znovu | publisher = Musicweb.cz | accessdate = 31 January 2014|language=cs}} Despite originally playing crossover, over time they have moved on to [[electronic rock]], fusing the common rock elements with an [[Electronic music|electronic]] instrumentation. == History == Many musicians had been turning in the band until 2008 when its line-up finally settled down in its permanent form: Jiří Sosik – guitar, Tomáš Frieb – guitar, Tomáš Klos – bass, Lukáš Kroutil – drums, Lukáš Kraut – vocals. In 2008 the group recorded its debut album called "No Turns" {{cite web | url = http://rockmag.cz/clanky/public-relations-no-turns/ | title = No Turns review on Rockmag.cz | publisher = Rockmag.cz | accessdate = 14 May 2011|language=cs}}{{cite web | url = http://www.praha-music-city.cz/?clanek=53&titulek=public-relations-no-turns | title = No Turns review by Petr Korál | publisher = Praha Music City|language=cs}} and started performing live in clubs and on music festivals, enhanced by a [[percussions|percussionist]] Tomáš Demel. The drummer Lukáš Kroutil left the band the next year and his place was filled by Marek Konečný, who had just come back from the [[United States|USA]], where he had been playing drums in a band called Cold Summer Society, after 13 years. Later, the band continued performing, however, without Tomáš Demel, who decided not to perform with Public Relations henceforward. Those days the band had been working hard on new material, which culminated in 2011 by releasing its sophomore album called "The Platinum Air".{{cite web | url = http://www.irockshock.net/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=2155 | title = The Platinum Air review | publisher = Rockshock | accessdate = 13 October 2011|language=cs}} After its release party and a series of live shows, the band was taking pause and Lukáš Kraut started working on his solo material. In July 2012 – the 8th anniversary of the band's existence – the vocalist decided to devote himself only to his solo career and left the band. The guitarist Tomáš Frieb left PUBLIC RELATIONS with him. == Present == In the beginning of 2013 the band found a replacement for the position of the [[frontman]] - the vocalist Jan Ražnok, who had been performing in many local bands and projects before. With their new singer, Public Relations prepared a new repertoire, which was released on their third studio [[Musical album|album]] {{cite web | url = http://www.studentpoint.cz/265-novinky/14062-public-relations-vypousti-do-sveta-treti-album-reset/ | title = The article about the release of the album Reset | publisher = Studentpoint.cz | accessdate = 9 February 2014 | language = cs | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150623155619/http://www.studentpoint.cz/265-novinky/14062-public-relations-vypousti-do-sveta-treti-album-reset/ | archivedate = 23 June 2015 | df = }}{{cite web | url = http://www.ostravan.cz/14445/public-relations-nekdy-je-potreba-zmacknout-pomyslne-tlacitko-reset/ | title = Interview with PUBLIC RELATIONS on Ostravan.cz | publisher = Ostravan.cz | accessdate = 25 April 2014|language=cs}} on 31 December 2013. == Current lineup == * Jan "Comar" Ražnok – vocals * Jiří Sosik – guitar * Tomáš Klos – bass * Marek Konečný – drums == Discography == * ''No Turns'', 2008 * ''The Platinum Air'', 2011 * ''Close To Sun'' ([[Extended play|EP]]), 2013 * ''Reset'', 2013 * ''Sirael'', 2016 {{Cite web|url=http://www.ostravan.cz/33487/public-relations-si-s-albem-sirael-ukousli-velke-sousto-za-vysledek-se-ale-stydet-nemusi/|title=Sirael review by Anna Neuwirthová on Ostravan.cz|last=|first=|date=27 July 2016|website=|publisher=|access-date=|language=cs}} {{Cite web|url=http://metalforever.info/article.php?id=31702|title=Sirael review by Savapip on metalforever.info|last=|first=|date=9 October 2016|website=|publisher=|access-date=|language=cs}} {{Cite web|url=http://www.fobiazine.net/article/9694/public-relations--sirael/|title=Sirael review by Mikael on Fobia zine|last=|first=|date=12 August 2016|website=|publisher=|access-date=|language=cs}} {{Cite web|url=http://www.hellmagazine.eu/cd_2016_153.html|title=Sirael review by Ďuro Haríň on Hellmagazine|last=|first=|date=1 November 2016|website=|publisher=|access-date=|language=sk}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website|http://public.relations.cz}} == Sources == * [[:cs:Public Relations (skupina)|Czech Wikipedia]] {{cs icon}} [[Category:Czech rock music groups]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 2004]] [[Category:European musical group stubs]] [[Category:Czech Republic stubs]] {{CzechRepublic-band-stub}}

'''Radio Volga''' ({{lang-ru|Радио Волга}}) was a [[radio station]] for the [[Red Army|Soviet armed forces]] stationed in the former [[East Germany]] and [[Czechoslovak Socialist Republic|Czechoslovakia]], broadcasting mainly in [[Russian language|Russian]].<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=djFiAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Radio+Volga%22+gdr&dq=%22Radio+Volga%22+gdr&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwio_4LD4KfLAhUHyRQKHTUBCigQ6AEIMDAA ''The Mass Media of the German-speaking Countries''], John Sandford, Oswald Wolff, 1976</ref>
==Broadcasting station== Based in Potsdam, Radio Volga broadcast from the [[Königs Wusterhausen radio transmitter|Königs Wusterhausen radio facility]] near [[Berlin]], as well as the [[Burg AM transmitter]] near [[Magdeburg]].<ref name ="WRTH">[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ENI6AAAAIAAJ&q=%22Radio+Volga%22++K%C3%B6nigs+Wusterhausen&dq=%22Radio+Volga%22++K%C3%B6nigs+Wusterhausen&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjSxuuG4qfLAhWFuRQKHUD5Cw8Q6AEILTAA ''World Radio TV Handbook''], Oluf Lund-Johansen Cardfont Publishers under license from Billboard Publications, 1974, page 70</ref>
From 1967 to 1976 Radio Volga used the 350-meter SL-3 tower, 2.2 kilometers from the transmitter. After it collapsed in 1976, one of the site's two 210-meter high steel tube masts was used instead. Radio Volga originally broadcast on the [[longwave]] frequency 283 [[kHz]].<ref name="Grull">[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YAwiAQAAIAAJ&q=%22Radio+Wolga%22+261+kHz&dq=%22Radio+Wolga%22+261+kHz&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjZxfXj5afLAhWF7xQKHa27DqsQ6AEINzAB ''Radio und Musik von und für Soldaten: Kriegs- und Nachkriegsjahre : 1939-1960''], Günter Grull, Herbst, 2000, page 16</ref>
==Programming== Beside programs for the [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] soldiers stationed in the GDR, Radio Volga also broadcast [[German language]] programmes from [[Radio Moscow]].<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=KXxJzHGJas0C&lpg=PA40&dq=%22FFB%22%20Radio%20%22Berlin%22%20%221994%22&pg=PA41#v=onepage&q=%22FFB%22%20Radio%20%22Berlin%22%20%221994%22&f=true ''Radiogeschichten: Zeitreise und Exkursionen in die Berliner RadioWelten''], Die Radionauten, BoD, 2005, page 41</ref> After [[German reunification]] in 1990, transmitting time was rented to the German-language news station [[Radioropa Info]], broadcasting on 261 kHz.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=wcxNAAAAYAAJ&q=%22Radio+Volga%22+261+kHz&dq=%22Radio+Volga%22+261+kHz&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjQ8Z2Y5KfLAhVD6xQKHayFAX8Q6AEIJjAA ''World Radio TV Handbook, Volume 48''], O. Lund Johansen, 1994, page 81</ref>
==Television== [[Soviet Central Television]]'s main channel, [[Programme One|TSS-1]], was also relayed in [[East Germany]] via satellite.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=jMdNAAAAYAAJ&dq=soviet+television+TSS+Berlin&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=TSS-1+ ''World Radio TV Handbook''], Volume 39, Billboard Publications, 1984, page 398</ref>
==Shutdown== With the departure of Russian troops from Germany, Radio Volga ceased broadcasting in June 1994.<ref name="Grull" /> [[Radioropa Info]] took over its frequency, broadcasting from late 1994 to 2000, first from [[Daun]] and then from [[Leipzig]].<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=qTUqAQAAIAAJ&q=Radioropa+Info&dq=Radioropa+Info&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj2s6bR56fLAhVJ8RQKHaaIA9EQ6AEILjAD ''World Radio TV Handbook''], Volume 51,Cardfont Publishers under license from Billboard Publications., 1997, page 88</ref> In 1999 a new cage aerial was mounted on the 324-meter radio mast in Burg.<ref>[http://www.radioheritage.net/europe/profile_burg.htm Station Profile - Burg 261 kHz]</ref>
==See also== *[[AFN Berlin]] *[[American Forces Network]] *[[British Forces Broadcasting Service]] *[[Radio forces françaises de Berlin]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050403112242/http://www.asamnet.de/~bienerhj/0261.html Burg, früher 261 kHz] {{de icon}} — brief history of transmissions on 261 kHz in Germany
[[Category:Brandenburg]] [[Category:Defunct radio stations in East Germany]] [[Category:German-language radio stations]] [[Category:External services (broadcasting)]] [[Category:Military of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Russian-language radio stations]] [[Category:Saxony-Anhalt]] [[Category:Military broadcasting]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1945]] [[Category:Radio stations disestablished in 1994]] [[Category:1945 establishments in East Germany]] [[Category:1994 disestablishments in Germany]]
