revision.text:
[[File:Waterway opspuiten zandsuppletie 355907s.jpg|thumb|250px|Rainbowing by the '''Waterway''']] '''Rainbowing''' is the process in which a [[Dredge|dredging]] ship propels sand that has been claimed from the ocean floor in a high arc to a particular location. This is used for multiple purposes, ranging from building up a beach to prevent [[erosion]] to constructing new islands. The name is derived from the appearance of the arc, which closely resembles a brown-colored rainbow.
This technique was used extensively in the construction of the [[Palm Islands]] and [[The World (archipelago)|The World, Dubai]].<ref name = "Van de Velde"/>
==Process== The process of rainbowing begins with the excavation of sediment, typically sand, from the seabed by a [[dredger]]. Dredgers excavate the sediment using mechanical or hydraulic methods or a combination of both.<ref name = "Dredging: the Facts">{{Cite book | title = Dredging: the Facts | year = 2005 | url= http://www.dredging.org/documents/ceda/downloads/publications-dredging_the_facts.pdf | publisher = WODA,IADC,PIANC,IAPH | isbn = 90-75254-11-3 | accessdate = 2013-02-04}}</ref> During the excavation process, large quantities of water are collected along with sediment creating a mixture called [[slurry]]. The slurry can then be utilised on-site or transported to where it will be deposited. The liquid characteristics of the slurry allow the dredger to transfer the slurry by ejecting it through the air in arcs.<ref name = "Linham">{{cite web |url = http://climatetechwiki.org/content/beach-nourishment |title = Beach nourishment |last1 = Linham |first1 = Matthew M. |last2 = Nicholls |first2 = Robert J. |accessdate = 2013-02-04}}</ref>
==Rainbowing nozzles== The projection of slurry for [[beach nourishment]] and other dredging uses is achieved through the use of nozzles which affect the output and trajectory of the slurry.
The diameter of the nozzle affects the output of the dredger and the distance that the slurry is projected. Smaller diameters, for instance, have less flow leading to lower hourly output, but are able to project the slurry over a further distance due to a higher exit velocity. Jumbo dredgers today can easily achieve distances in excess of 150 metres, but at the cost of 30% extra discharge time.<ref name = "Van de Velde">{{cite web |url = http://www.theartofdredging.com/rainbowing.htm |title = Rainbowing |last = Van de Velde |first = Marc |date = March 2008 |accessdate = 2013-02-04}}</ref>
Nozzles that are angled 30° from the horizontal are standard. Although 45° nozzle angles achieve longer distances from a ballistics perspective, 45° nozzles have been observed to create large craters. In addition, a high amount of sand flows back towards the dredger. 30° nozzles instead project the sand with a flatter trajectory, minimizing back flow while achieving a final distance comparable to that reached by a 45° nozzle.<ref name = "Van de Velde" />
Other methods of disposing and transferring the slurry include pumping the slurry through pipelines or using natural forces such as wave currents.<ref name = Linham/>
==Advantages== Since rainbowing transfers material by ejecting it through the air, the technique is useful for reclaiming areas that are too shallow for direct placement.<ref name = "PIANC">{{Cite book | year = 2010 | author = PIANC EnviCom Working Group 108 | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=zGXpWS4KtjQC&pg=PA17&lpg=PA17&dq=Dredging+rainbowing&source=bl&ots=Qq5AYPP5BI&sig=DgT2dH6Z36vo00ljunadWaq3jic&hl=en&sa=X&ei=PpYQUfmwI8Pi2QX38ICQAQ&ved=0CGUQ6AEwCw#v=onepage&q=Dredging%20rainbowing&f=false | title = Dredging and Port Construction Around Coral Reefs | publisher = PIANC | series = Issue 108 of PIANC report | isbn = 9782872231775 | accessdate = 2013-02-04}} pp. 17</ref> In addition, rainbowing allows the dredger to dispose excavated sediment on-site. This is useful for dredging operations such as creating [[trench]]es since the dredger can simply cast the excavated sediment to the side as opposed to spending time dumping or transporting the collected sediment. This allows for a continuous trenching operation.<ref name = "Van de Velde"/>
==Environmental impact== Rainbowing, along with other dredging and reclamation methods, has various effects on the environment apart from vastly changing its geographical structure.
Throughout the dredging and nourishment process, plumes of fine sediment, which can take longer to settle, can remain suspended in the water for long periods of time. These clouds of fine sediment can have adverse effects on the ecosystem, asphyxiating fish and other fauna as well as blocking sunlight. As organisms die, the water becomes toxic as decomposed organic materials raise [[hydrogen sulfide]] levels. In such cases, it is often impossible for an ecosystem to revive. It often takes a couple years for the ecosystem to recover, when recovery does occur.<ref name = "Palm Island">{{cite web |url = https://sites.google.com/site/palmislandsimpact/environmental-impacts/initial |title = The Impact of the Palm Islands, United Arab Emirates |accessdate = 2013-02-04}}</ref> In addition, coral can be removed or become buried by the sediment.<ref name = "PIANC"/> {{See also|Dredge#Environmental_impacts}}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * https://web.archive.org/web/20061117204621/http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/channel/totalmegastructures/photogallery_rainbowing_island.html * http://www.accessmylibrary.com/premium/0286/0286-11654915.html
[[Category:Coastal construction]] [[Category:Ocean pollution]]

revision.comment: replace [[Category:Cultural heritage]] with [[Category:Cultural heritage organizations]] to assist with the tidy up of the former category
revision.text:
The '''Sustainable Preservation Initiative''' (SPI) is a not-for-profit organization dedicated to preserving the world's [[cultural heritage]] by providing transformative and sustainable economic opportunities to local communities. SPI is focused on countries in the developing world, more particularly those that are not part of the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] as well as [[Mexico]], [[Greece]] and [[Turkey]]. SPI seeks to encourage and develop sustainable economic development in the communities surrounding archaeological sites by aiding in the development of locally owned businesses that maximize the spending of dollars in these communities and regions. Some [[manufacturing]] industries are aided as well, including local [[artisan]]s. SPI's projects provide a two-for-the-price-of-one benefit: they create viable economic opportunities for the local residents while saving archaeological sites for future generations to study and enjoy.<ref>http://www.sustainablepreservation.org/</ref>
According to Felix Salmon of Reuters, SPI is about taking archaeological sites "in poor countries and making them generate cash for the locals — thereby giving them a real monetary incentive (rather than a high-minded lecture) aimed at preserving archeological treasures."<ref>http://blogs.reuters.com/felix-salmon/2009/06/09/better-living-through-archeology/</ref> In an article on job creation, Salmon cites SPI as a model for maximum job creation through small investments: "In general, if you want to create the maximum number of jobs for the smallest amount of money, the best way of doing so is to provide catalytic capital which helps to give a small business the step-up it needs to sustain new jobs on a permanent basis".<ref>http://blogs.reuters.com/felix-salmon/2010/03/08/job-creation-datapoints-of-the-day/</ref> In a recent report, the [[Milken Institute]] called for the adoption of SPI's model by the state of Israel in order to better protect that country's cultural heritage.<ref>http://www.marketwire.com/press-release/Israel-Needs-Archaeological-Business-Models-Increase-Economic-Development-Value-Cultural-1389503.htm</ref> Handeye Magazine, an international publication dedicated to culture and commerce, cites the organization as one that "continues to put 'people, not stones' at the forefront, placing equal or greater focus on economic and social investment as opposed to purely preservation."<ref>http://handeyemagazine.com/content/people-not-stones/</ref> BigThink.com, a website that seeks to identify the "best thinking on the planet — the ideas that can help you think flexibly and act decisively in a multivariate world," featured SPI's paradigm for preservation and its success.<ref>http://bigthink.com/ideas/38801/</ref>
SPI is active at ten sites in [[Peru]], as well as in Guatemala and Jordan. The SPI mantra is "Build Futures, Save Pasts." The program's executive director is archaeologist [[Larry Coben]]. SPI was incubated at the [[Cotsen Institute of Archaeology]] at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] and the [[Archaeological Institute of America]].
==References==
{{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.sustainablepreservation.org/ Official site-Sustainable Preservation Initiative] *[http://peoplenotstones.org/ 'People Not Stones' Official Blog for SPI]
[[Category:International economic organizations]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Cultural heritage organizations]] [[Category:Archaeological organisations]]

{{Infobox |above=TDF time code transmitter |image=[[Image:emetteur-allouis3.jpg|270px]] |caption=The 350 m high [[low frequency]] antennas of TDF time signal in Allouis |label1=Location |data1=[[Allouis longwave transmitter]], [[Allouis]], France |label2=Coordinates |data2={{coord|47.1695|N|2.2046|E|type:landmark_region:FR|display=it}} |label3=Elevation |data3={{convert|129|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} |label4=Operator |data4=[[TéléDiffusion de France]] on behalf of the LNE–SYRTE |label5=Frequency |data5=162 kHz |label6=Power |data6=1,500 kW (1,000 kW at night 00-06h) |label7=Began operation |data7=July 1980 |label8=Ceased operation |data8= |label9=Official range |data9={{convert|3500|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} |label10=Website |data10= }} [[TDF Group|TéléDiffusion de France]] broadcast the '''TDF''' [[time signal]], controlled by LNE–SYRTE, from the [[Allouis longwave transmitter]] at 162 kHz, with a power of 2 MW.[http://syrte.obspm.fr/gen/accueil_en.php SYRTE website] It was also known as '''FI''' or '''France Inter''' because the signal was formerly best known for broadcasting the [[France Inter]] [[Amplitude modulation|AM signal]]. This signal ceased at the end of 2016, but the transmitter remains in use for its time signal and other digital signals. In 1980, the first [[atomic clock]] was installed to regulate the [[carrier frequency]].{{fr icon}}[http://pagesperso-orange.fr/tvignaud/am/allouis/allouis4.htm Les ré-orientations] The current time signal is generated by an extremely accurate [[caesium]] fountain atomic clock and phase-modulated on the 162 kHz carrier in a way that is inaudible when listening to the France Inter signal using a normal AM receivers. It requires a more complex receiver than the popular [[DCF77]] service, but the much more powerful transmitter (22 to 40 times DCF77's 50 kW) gives it a much greater range of 3,500 km. The signal is almost continuous but there is a regularly scheduled interruption for maintenance every Tuesday. This used to be from 01:03 to 05:00, but with the cessation of audio signals, it has been moved to 08:00 to 12:00.{{cite web |url=http://www.anfr.fr/gestion-des-frequences-sites/signal-horaire/les-tests-du-signal-horaire/ |title=Les tests du signal horaire |trans-title=The tests of the time signal |language=fr |publisher=Agence Nationale des Fréquences |access-date=2017-03-16}} The signal was formerly 2,000 kW, but has been reduced to 1,500 kW, and tests are in progress of a further reduction to 1,100 kW for cost savings. ==Signal format== TéléDiffusion de France (TDF) uses an [[amplitude modulation|amplitude modulated]] [[longwave]] [[transmitter station]]. Time signals are transmitted by [[phase modulation|phase-modulating]] the carrier by ±1 [[radian]] in 0.1 s every second except the 59th second of each minute. This modulation pattern is repeated to indicate a binary one. The binary encoding of date and time data during seconds 15 through 59 is identical to that of [[DCF77]]; the numbers of the minute, hour, day of the month, day of the week, month and year are transmitted each minute from the 21st to the 58th second, in accordance with the French legal time scale. The time transmitted is the local time of the upcoming minute. Also like DCF77, bit 20 is always 1, bit 18 indicates that local time is UTC+1 (CET), bit 17 indicates that local time is UTC+2 (CEST), and bit 16 indicates that a change to local time will take place at the end of the current hour. Bit 15 is reserved to indicate abnormal transmitter operation. As extensions to the DCF77 code, bit 14 is set during public holidays (14 July, Christmas, etc.), and bit 13 is set the day before public holidays.[ftp://ftp2.bipm.org/pub/tai/scale/timesignals.pdf Time signals known to BIPM] Unlike DCF77, bit 19 is not used for [[leap second]] warnings, but is always zero. Instead, bit 1 is used to warn of a positive leap second, and bit 2 is used to warn of a (very unlikely) negative leap second.{{cite web |title=Radio signals during a leap second |first=Emmanuel |last=Fuste |url=http://pa3fwm.nl/signals/leapsecond-2016/ |date=31 January 2017 |accessdate=9 March 2017 |quote=Thanks to people at Agence Nationale des Fréquences (ANFR) and Chambre française de l'horlogerie et des microtechniques (CFHM) I got a copy of Norme Française NF C 90-002 from August 1988, describing the format of the TDF time signal. The leap second announcement bits are in fact the 2nd (for positive leapsecond) and 3rd (for negative) bits in the minute. The positive leap second is to be inserted by inserting an extra 0 bit after the 3rd bit of the last minute of the hour.}} In case of a leap second, an additional zero bit is inserted between bits 2 and 3. This is supposed to be inserted at 23:59:03, during minute 59 of the hour (during which the timestamp for minute :00 is transmitted), so that the minute markers are all broadcast at the correct times, but for the leap second at the end of December 2016, it was apparently inserted at 23:58:03. The relative uncertainty of the carrier frequency is 2 parts in 1012. {|class=wikitable style="text-align:center" |+ TDF time code ! Bit || Weight || Meaning |rowspan=21| ! Bit || Weight || Meaning |rowspan=21| ! Bit || Weight || Meaning |- |bgcolor=#ffccff| :00 ||bgcolor=#ffccff| M ||bgcolor=#ffccff| Start of minute, always 0. |bgcolor=#ffccff| :20 ||bgcolor=#ffccff| S ||bgcolor=#ffccff| Start of encoded time, always 1. |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :40 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 10 ||rowspan=2 bgcolor=#ccffcc|Day of month (continued) |- |bgcolor=#ccffff| :01 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| A2 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| Positive [[Leap second|leap second]] warning.
Set during previous hour |bgcolor=#ffffcc| :21 ||bgcolor=#ffffcc| 1 ||rowspan=7 bgcolor=#ffffcc| Minutes
00–59 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :41 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 20 |- |bgcolor=#ccffff| :02 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| A3 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| Negative leap second warning.
Set during previous hour |bgcolor=#ffffcc| :22 ||bgcolor=#ffffcc| 2 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :42 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 1 ||rowspan=3 bgcolor=#ccffcc| Day of week
Monday=1, Sunday=7 |- |bgcolor=#ccffff| :03 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| 1 ||rowspan="4" bgcolor=#ccffff| Half of count of bits
21–58 set to 1[http://www.radiotecnia.es/la-senal-horaria-anfr-en-162-khz-iii/ ANFR time signal (in Spanish), updated time data description]
(maybe 2–13, no [[Binary-coded decimal|BCD]]) |bgcolor=#ffffcc| :23 ||bgcolor=#ffffcc| 4 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :43 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 2 |- |bgcolor=#ccffff| :04 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| 2 |bgcolor=#ffffcc| :24 ||bgcolor=#ffffcc| 8 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :44 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 4 |- |bgcolor=#ccffff| :05 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| 4 |bgcolor=#ffffcc| :25 ||bgcolor=#ffffcc| 10 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :45 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 1 ||rowspan=5 bgcolor=#ccffcc| Month number
01–12 |- |bgcolor=#ccffff| :06 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| 8 |bgcolor=#ffffcc| :26 ||bgcolor=#ffffcc| 20 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :46 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 2 |- | :07 || 0 | rowspan="6" |Unused, always 0 |bgcolor=#ffffcc| :27 ||bgcolor=#ffffcc| 40 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :47 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 4 |- | :08 || 0 |bgcolor=#ffffcc| :28 ||bgcolor=#ffffcc| P1 ||bgcolor=#ffffcc| [[Even parity]] over minute bits 21–28. |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :48 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 8 |- | :09 || 0 |bgcolor=#ffcccc| :29 ||bgcolor=#ffcccc| 1 ||rowspan=6 bgcolor=#ffcccc| Hours
0–23 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :49 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 10 |- | :10 || 0 |bgcolor=#ffcccc| :30 ||bgcolor=#ffcccc| 2 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :50 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 1 ||rowspan=8 bgcolor=#ccffcc| Year within century
00–99 |- | :11 || 0 |bgcolor=#ffcccc| :31 ||bgcolor=#ffcccc| 4 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :51 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 2 |- | :12 || 0 |bgcolor=#ffcccc| :32 ||bgcolor=#ffcccc| 8 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :52 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 4 |- |bgcolor=#ccffff| :13 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| F1 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| Following day is a public holiday. |bgcolor=#ffcccc| :33 ||bgcolor=#ffcccc| 10 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :53 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 8 |- |bgcolor=#ccffff| :14 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| F2 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| Current day is a public holiday. |bgcolor=#ffcccc| :34 ||bgcolor=#ffcccc| 20 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :54 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 10 |- | :15 || 0 || To be ignored. |bgcolor=#ffcccc| :35 ||bgcolor=#ffcccc| P2 ||bgcolor=#ffcccc| Even parity over hour bits 29–35. |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :55 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 20 |- |bgcolor=#ccffff| :16 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| A1 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| [[Daylight saving time|Summer time]] announcement.
Set during hour before change. |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :36 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 1 ||rowspan=4 bgcolor=#ccffcc| Day of month.
01–31 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :56 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 40 |- |bgcolor=#ccffff| :17 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| Z1 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| Set to 1 when [[Central European Summer Time|CEST]] is in effect. |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :37 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 2 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :57 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 80 |- |bgcolor=#ccffff| :18 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| Z2 ||bgcolor=#ccffff| Set to 1 when [[Central European Time|CET]] is in effect. |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :38 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 4 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :58 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| P3 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| Even parity over date bits 36–58. |- | :19 || 0 || Unused, always 0 |bgcolor=#ccffcc| :39 ||bgcolor=#ccffcc| 8 |bgcolor=#ff88ff| :59 ||colspan=2 bgcolor=#ff88ff| No bit transmitted during last second of each minute. |} ==Phase modulation pattern== One signal element consists of the phase of the carrier shifted linearly by +1 rad in 25 ms (known as "ramp A"), then shifted linearly by −2 rad over 50 ms ("ramp B"), then shifted linearly again by +1 rad for another 25 ms ("ramp C"), returning the phase to zero. One signal element is always sent at each second between 0 and 58. Two signal elements are sent in sequence to represent a binary one; otherwise it is interpreted as binary zero. During ramp B of the initial signal element, the exact point the signal phase is at zero represents the top of the UTC second. Since the phase is the integral of the frequency, this triangular phase modulation at 40 rad/s corresponds to a square frequency modulation with a deviation of 20/''π'' ≈ 6.37 Hz. [[Image:TDF phase modulation bit pattern.svg]] Both the average phase and the average frequency deviation are thus zero. Additional non-timing data is sent by phase modulation during the rest of each second. But the second marker (and data bit) is always preceded by 100 ms without any phase modulation. The signal is not phase-modulated at all during the 59th second past the minute. ==See also== * [[Loop antenna#AM broadcast receiver loop antennas|Loop antenna]] * [[Allouis longwave transmitter]], the facility used for its transmission. * [[TéléDiffusion de France]] (also known as the [[TDF Group]]) ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== * {{cite web |url=http://www.longwave.de/TSS.pdf |title=Standard Frequency and Time Signal Stations On Longwave and Shortwave |accessdate=2006-10-27 |last=Betke |first=Klaus |date=2006-07-01 |format=PDF |pages=9–10 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060818020829/http://www.longwave.de/TSS.pdf |archivedate = 2006-08-18}} * David L. Mills, ''Information on Time and Frequency'' — [http://www.eecis.udel.edu/~mills/ntp/tdf.html Time and Standard Frequency Station TDF (France)] * {{de icon}} [http://www.leunig.de/_pro/netzwerk/funkuhr/funkuhren_DCF77_TDF.htm Funkuhren—Vergleich DCF77 mit TDF] ("Clocks—Compare DCF77 with TDF") Includes a map showing the different reception ranges. * {{fr icon}} http://pagesperso-orange.fr/tvignaud/am/allouis/allouis-heure.htm * {{fr icon}} [http://www.datelec.fr/signaux_horaires/p0.htm Signaux Horaires] Description of the TDF signal and a working receiver. {{TimeSig}} {{Time signal Authorities}} {{Time Topics}} {{Time measurement and standards}} [[Category:Time signal radio stations]] [[fr:Émetteur d'Allouis]]

revision.text:
{{Time zones of Europe}} [[Europe]] spans seven primary [[time zone]]s (from [[UTC−01:00]] to [[UTC+05:00]]), excluding [[daylight saving time|summer time]] offsets (four of them can be seen on the map to the right, with one further-western zone containing the [[Azores]], and two further-eastern zones spanning [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Azerbaijan]], eastern territories of [[European Russia]], and the European part of [[Kazakhstan]]). Most European countries use summer time and harmonise their summer time adjustments. See [[Summer time in Europe]] for details. The time zones actually in use in Europe differ significantly from uniform zoning based purely on longitude, as used for example under the [[nautical time]] system. The world could in theory be divided into 24 time zones, each of 15 degrees of longitude. However, due to geographical and cultural factors it is not practical to divide the world so evenly, and actual time zones may differ significantly from those based purely on longitude. In Europe, the widespread use of Central European Time (CET) causes major variations in some areas from [[solar time]]. Based on solar time, CET would range from 7.5 to 22.5°E. However, for example Spain (almost entirely in the Western hemisphere) and France (almost entirely west of 7.5°E, as illustrated in the map below) should theoretically use UTC, as they did before the Second World War.{{cite journal |last=Poulle |first=Yvonne |title=La France à l'heure allemande |trans-title=France on German time |journal={{lang|fr|Bibliothèque de l'école des chartes}} |year=1999 |volume=157 |issue=2 |pages=493–502 |url=http://www.persee.fr/articleAsPDF/bec_0373-6237_1999_num_157_2_450989/article_bec_0373-6237_1999_num_157_2_450989.pdf |accessdate=11 January 2012 }} {{fr icon}}{{dead link|date=April 2016}} The general result is a solar noon which is much later than clock noon, and later sunrises and sunsets than should theoretically happen. The Benelux countries should also theoretically use GMT. Russia and Belarus observed "permanent summer time" between March 2011 and October 2014.{{cite news |last=Parfitt |first=Tom |title=Think of the cows: clocks go forward for the last time in Russia |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/25/clocks-go-forward-last-time-russia |accessdate=5 January 2012 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=25 March 2011 }} Since October 2014 Russia has observed "permanent winter time". Iceland can be considered to be on "''de facto''" permanent summer time because, since 1968, it uses UTC time all year, despite being located more than 15° west of the prime meridian. It should therefore be located in UTC−1, but chooses to remain closer to continental European time, resulting in legal times significantly in advance of local solar time; this is of little practical significance owing to the wide variations in daylight hours in that country. The [[European Commission]] has proposed ending the practice of [[Summer Time in Europe|Summer time in the EU]] and [[EFTA]] countries in 2019. However, the decision lies with the EU's Member States as a group. [http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_MEMO-18-5641_en.htm State of the Union 2018: Q&A on the Commission's proposal to put an end to seasonal clock changes] [[European Commission]] − Press Release (Strasbourg, 12 September 2018) {| |- style="vertical-align: top" | | [[File:Tzdiff-Europe-winter.png|220px|thumb|This map shows the difference between legal time and local mean time in Europe during the winter. Most of Western Europe and western part of European Russia are significantly ahead of local solar time.]] {| class="wikitable" cellpadding="4" ! Colour !! Legal time vs local mean time |- | style="background: #8f8fbf;" | | 1 h ± 30 m behind |- | style="background: #bfbfbf;" | | 0 h ± 30 m |- | style="background: #bf8f8f;" | | 1 h ± 30 m ahead |- | style="background: #bf6060;" | | 2 h ± 30 m ahead |} | [[File:Tzdiff-Europe-summer.png|220px|thumb|This map shows the difference between legal time and local mean time in Europe during the summer. Most of Western Europe is significantly ahead of local solar time.]] {| class="wikitable" cellpadding="4" ! Colour !! Legal time vs local mean time |- | style="background:#c8bfe7;" | | 1 h ± 30 m behind |- | style="background:#bfbfbf;" | | 0 h ± 30 m |- | style="background: #bf8f8f;" | | 1 h ± 30 m ahead |- | style="background: #bf6060;" | | 2 h ± 30 m ahead |- | style="background: #bf0000;" | | 3 h ± 30 m ahead |} |} ==Use== Of the 28 EU member states: *[[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], [[Portugal]] ([[Continental Portugal]] and [[Madeira]]) and the [[United Kingdom]] use [[Western European Time]]. *[[Finland]], [[Estonia]], [[Latvia]], [[Lithuania]], [[Romania]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Greece]] and [[Cyprus]] use [[Eastern European Time]] *[[Austria]], [[Belgium]], [[Croatia]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Denmark]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Hungary]], [[Italy]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Malta]], [[Netherlands]], [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]], [[Slovenia]], [[Spain]] (apart from [[Canary Islands]] that observing the [[Western European Time]]) and [[Sweden]] use [[Central European Time]]. [[Norway]], [[Switzerland]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Serbia]], [[Kosovo]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]], [[Montenegro]], [[San Marino]], [[Vatican City]], [[Andorra]], [[Monaco]] and [[Liechtenstein]] also observe Central European Time. [[Northern Cyprus]] and [[Transnistria]] observe Eastern European Time. [[Azores]] in [[Portugal]] observes the [[Atlantic/Azores]] Time (UTC−1 with Daylight saving time in the summer). [[Iceland]] observes the [[Western European Time]]. [[Moldova]], [[Kaliningrad Oblast]] ([[Kaliningrad Time]]) and [[Ukraine]] (apart from [[Crimea]]) observe the [[Eastern European Time]]. [[Belarus]], [[Russia]] (western part, including [[Crimean Federal District|Crimea]]) and [[Turkey]] use [[Further-eastern European Time]]. [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]], [[Armenia]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[South Ossetia]], [[Abkhazia]], [[Nagorno-Karabakh]] follow different Time Zones, including [[Samara Time]], [[Yekaterinburg Time]], the Asian Time Zones of Russia, [[UTC+04:00]] (Armenia, Georgia and Azerbaijan including Nagorno-Karabakh), [[UTC+05:00]] (Kazakhstan). ==Differences between cites== [[London]] and others: {| class="wikitable" ! Time of Day || City name |- valign="top" | {{time|UTC±00:00|df=y}} || [[London]] (WET) |- valign="top" style="border-top:hidden;" | {{time|UTC+01:00|df=y}} || [[Berlin]] (CET) |} {| class="wikitable" ! Time of Day || City name |- valign="top" | {{time|UTC±00:00|df=y}} || [[London]] (WET) |- valign="top" style="border-top:hidden;" | {{time|UTC+02:00|df=y}} || [[Kiev]] (EET) |} {| class="wikitable" ! Worldwide (Internet) | branding = | slogan = Classic Soul and Disco | airdate = 26 June 2000
(ended 4 April 2008) | frequency = | format = Soul | power = | erp = | class = | callsign_meaning = | former_callsigns = The Groove | owner = [[TIML Radio Limited]] | sister_stations = [[Absolute Radio]]
[[Absolute Classic Rock]]
[[Absolute Radio 60s]]
[[Absolute Radio 70s]]
[[Absolute 80s]]
[[Absolute Radio 90s]]
[[Absolute Radio 00s]]
[[Absolute Radio Extra]] | webcast = | website = [http://www.virginradio.co.uk/groove/ www.virginradio.co.uk/groove/] (formerly [http://www.virginradiogroove.co.uk/ www.virginradiogroove.co.uk]) | affiliations = }} A sister station to [[Virgin Radio]], '''Virgin Radio Groove''' was a former [[radio station]] broadcasting worldwide on the [[internet]]. The station closed officially on 31 December 2007; however, it continued to broadcast until 4 April 2008. It was launched as '''The Groove''' on 26 June 2000, and was renamed '''Virgin Radio Groove''' in 2004. It played [[Motown Records|motown]], [[soul music|soul]] and [[disco]] music and the first song played on The Groove was "[[ABC (song)|ABC]]" by the [[Jackson 5]]. As well as being broadcast on the [[internet]], Virgin Radio Groove also broadcast on [[Digital audio broadcasting|DAB]] in [[London]] and selected digital television networks ([[Sky Digital (UK & Ireland)|Sky Digital]] and [[Virgin Media]]). On 5 September 2005 the station was temporarily replaced by [[Virgin Radio Xtreme]] on DAB in London, but returned in early 2006 as a part-time service, daily from 7.00pm to 6.00am. ==Closure== Virgin Radio Groove was due to close down at the end of 2007. This came after it was revealed that plans to launch Virgin Radio Viva, which would have been on the new [[Channel 4]] platform and aimed at 15 to 29-year-old women, have been scrapped.{{cite news | title = Virgin Radio cuts back digital operation | publisher = VirginRadioWorld.com | date = November 2007 | url = http://www.bnnnews.it/virginsite.asp?MyVar=cuts | accessdate = 2007-11-27 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071121144837/http://www.bnnnews.it/virginsite.asp?MyVar=cuts |archivedate = 21 November 2007}} Between January and April 2008, the station still operated on all platforms, albeit entirely automated, and the official website was not updated since a message was added about the station's closure in 2007. [[File:VirginRadioGroove.png]] Virgin Radio Groove ceased broadcasting completely and was removed from the [[Sky Digital (UK & Ireland)|Sky]] [[Electronic Programme Guide|EPG]] on 4 April 2008. The online streams also closed down. On the former frequency of Eurobird 1 11390V It is currently showing a 16 Hz test tone for 1 day and then silent. The station's former channel existed on the [[Virgin Media]] EPG with a message mentioning the closure of the station in place of the programme titles until 17 April when [[Virgin Media]] removed it from their lineup. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.virginradiogroove.co.uk VirginRadioGroove.co.uk] {{Absolute Radio}} [[Category:Virgin Radio (UK)| ]] [[Category:Internet radio stations in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Defunct radio stations in the United Kingdom]] {{internet-bcast-stub}}

It is also distributed in [[Southeast Asia]] and [[Europe]]. It was first launched in 1997 as Music Asia, rebranded as Zee Music in 2000 and finally rebranded as Zing in April 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.televisionpoint.com/news2009/newsfullstory.php?id%3D1238594940 |title=Zee Muzic transforms itself into Zing|accessdate=17 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |date=1 April 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415080048/http://www.televisionpoint.com/news2009/newsfullstory.php?id=1238594940 |archivedate=15 April 2009 }} Zing features [[humour]], [[animation]], [[parody|spoofs]] and [[celebrity]] [[lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]] in addition to [[music]]. Zing also has Chillax Mornings, a non-stop musical programming block.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} In the UK, Zee Muzic was rebranded as Zing on 2 October 2009.{{cite
